msDesc.head: Astrology; England, 15th century, second quarter or middle

msItem.rubric: Tabula ad sciendum quis planeta regnat
msItem.note: Table of planetary hours for a week beginning on Sunday (as, for example, The Kalendarium of Nicholas of Lynn, ed. S. Eisner (Athens, GA, 1980), pp. 17-18, 176-7); but with only 23 rows, so the columns run Sol, Mercurius, Saturnus, Mars, Venus, Luna, Iubiter.

msItem.title: Mnemonic verses
msItem.incipit: Sol atque Venus boni Saturnus Marsque maligni | Sol et Mercurius cum Luna sunt mediocres
msItem.explicit: Ordine retrogrado quisquis sibi vindicat horam
msItem.note: Four verses, the first two as Kalendarium, ed. Eisner, p. 177.

msItem.title: Lunary: prognostication for a journey
msItem.incipit: Whan the mone [image] is in the whethir [image] go out. In the bole [image] abide for why if þu passe out þu doost thi self gret harm. Whan he is in geminis that is to sei both man an woman [image] go thi wai for than thu schalt finde a frende
msItem.explicit: Whan he is in the signe of fissches go not out for þu schalt be pore in þi going and in thi gein turnyng. Knowe þu for a certein reule þat whan þe mone is in the signe of an gode it is to begynne to seke þat þu askest wilfully, and whan he is in that signe the þinges þat þu sechest as matrimonie and edificacion and oþer swich it betokeneþ. Whan þe signe of Gemin regneþ hit be tokeneþ þinges double to be don. Whan þe mone is in þis signe to loke any membre or to touche it is euil.
msItem.note: The rules for the position of the moon in the zodiac are close to those in the text Proportiones competentes in astrorum industria, c. 10 (David Juste, Les Alchandreana primitifs : étude sur les plus anciens traités astrologiques latins d’origine arabe (Xe siècle) (Leiden, 2007), pp. 187-8, 516-7)

listBibl.bibl: Irma Taavitsainen, ‘The identification of Middle English lunary Mss.’, Neuphilologische Mitteilungen 88 (1987), p. 26

msItem.title: Mnemonic verses
msItem.incipit: Ignea sunt Aries Leo Sagitarius Taurus, terrea sunt Caper et Vir
Quattuor sunt elementa scilicet ignis calidus et siccus
msItem.note: Seven verses: five on the signs, two on the elements.

msItem.title: Table to find in which sign the moon is located on a given day (?)
msItem.note: Cf. for example, Kalendarium of Nicholas of Lynn, ed. Eisner, pp. 22-24, 182-3, but here miscopied, with 12 columns and 12 rows, and with Virgo and Libra missing, so that Leo is followed by Scorpio. There is no column for the age of the moon, and above the columns are added the names of the months from March to February.

msItem.rubric: Duodecim sunt signa scilicet Aries Taurus Gemins Cancer Leo Virgo Libra Scorpio Sagittarius Caprinus Aquarius Pisses Aries
msItem.incipit: In þe first constitucion of þe world toke virgi first þe hed of a man. The bole haþ the nekk and þe þrete. Geminis þe armes vn to þe hand. Cancer þe brest and þe longes. Leo þe stomak. Virgo haþ þe entrayles
msItem.explicit: [penwork] beþ hoot and moyste be nature of Jouis and Veneris [penwork] be cold and moyste by nature of þe mone ilych eyvn
msItem.note: References to genitalia are apparently replaced with blue and red penwork, cf. "Scorpius haþ [penwork]".

msItem.title: The Wise Book of Philosophy and Astronomy
msItem.incipit: Here beginneth of Astronomie and of philosophie contriued and y mad of the wisest philosephers and Astronomers þat euer were sitthen þis world was begunne That is for to seie of þe longe of Greke. For in þat londe an englissch man ful wise and wel vndirstondinge
msItem.explicit: he schal haue prosperyte he schal leue longe but ȝef þe cours of þe mone be more contrarius to hym

listBibl.bibl: ed. Griffin, sig. B6 (desc. p. xxix)

msItem.title: The Book of Destinary
msItem.incipit: Now hit is to declare of the xij signes of ther kyndes which eche man and woman is iordeyned by wey of kynd and predestinacion. And fyrst y schal determyn of þe signe of Aries þat regneþ in Marche
msItem.explicit: And sche ascape .xxx. wynter sche schal leue an .C. wynter. Her good days be Mondaye Thursday Fryday, and Tuesday and Saturday is evell. Now hit is to wete that what man or woman wol properleche deme the leuyng and þe predestinacion of man or of woman by þese forseid .xij. signes and .vij. planetes and .iiij. elementes him be houeþ to be hold and folow þe perilous termes of þe kalendar þenne trewleche and prophitableche he may þer of ȝeue a dome.
msItem.note: On the text see Griffin, pp. xlvii-xlix, with references to earlier literature.

extent.seg: ii (modern paper endleaves) + 18 + xii (blank modern paper) + ii (modern paper endleaves)

supportDesc.collation: 1(8), 2(8), 3(two); catchwords fols. 8v, 16v; one leaf signature '.b.j.', fol. 9r.

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled in ink for 32 long lines; ruled space c. 125 85

decoDesc.decoNote: "Good miniatures" (Pächt and Alexander iii. 800): small miniatures of the moon and signs of the zodiac in the lunary on fol. 1v. The artist has apparently misunderstood 'whethir' and drawn clouds instead of a ram.

4- to 2-line blue initials flourished in red (one red initial flourished in blue, fol. 8r); penwork borders in red and blue (fols. 1v, 3r); line-fillers in red and blue penwork; rubrics in red; intermittent majuscules in red.

history.provenance: No. 2547 in a 19th cent bookseller's catalogue (cutting, fol. ii verso)

"When catalogued in Jan. 1885 the volume bore the modern armorial bookplate of Stephen Couchman, which has now disappeared" (Summary Catalogue): perhaps Stephen Couchman of London, printer, fl. 1779-1824 (on whom see Ian Maxsted, 'The London book trades 1775-1800: a preliminary checklist of members', Exeter Working Papers in Book History)
history.acquisition: Bought from John D. Denman, London bookseller, on May 29, 1869, for £3 3s.

recordHist.source: Description by Matthew Holford, October 2025. Previously described: Summary Catalogue, Vol. 5, p. 535
